coredata.dc:title: Multifunctional polymer electrolyte membrane networks for energy storage via ion-dipole complexation in lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Lee, Hyunsang
Li, Ran
Piedrahita, Camilo Rendon
Cao, Jinwei
Kyu, Thein
coredata.dc:description: A novel concept of energy storage is presented involving ion-dipole complexation within multifunctional polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM), consisting of polyethylene glycol diacrylate (PEGDA) and succinonitrile (SCN) plasticizer and lithium bis-trifluoromethane sulfonyl imide (LiTFSI) salt. A similar complexation of lithium ions with ether oxygen and amine moieties occurs in the thermally cured poly(ethylene glycol) diglycidyl ether (PEGDGE) - polyether amine (Jeffamine D400, 2-arm) co-network. By virtue of the network functional groups, the ion transport is hindered which may be viewed as temporally holding of the Li ions, reminiscent of ion storage. Although some Li ions may be partially immobilized due to ion-dipole complexation, upon prelithiation via deep discharging the lithium metal/PEM/lithium iron phosphate (LFP) battery assembly to the low potential range of 0.01–0.5 V (i.e., oxidation at the Li metal anode), excess mobile Li ions become available that can travel to the cathode through the Li+ saturated complexation sites at ease, exhibiting high ionic conductivity with energy storage capability within the PEM matrix. Another way of supplying Li ions to PEM is through diffusion driven by ion concentration gradient between the two-layer PEM composite composed of a high salt concentration layer and a no-salt layer. The CV measurement was carried out as a function of aging time on the bilayer composite in the PEM potential range of 0.01 to 2.5 V, which indeed revealed a systematic emergence of redox reaction peaks, thereby validating the energy storing concept of the multifunctional PEM network.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Multifunctional polymer co-network
Polymer lithium metal battery
Prelithiation
Ion-dipole complexation

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) Chemical structures of poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA), LiTFSI salt, SCN plasticizer, and amine-epoxy reaction of between poly(ethylene glycol) diglycidyl ether (PEGDGE) and Jeffamine D400; (b) Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) scan of 20/40/40 PEGDA/SCN/LiTFSI (upper) and PEGDGE-co-Jeffamine (70:30 wt%)/SCN/LiTFSI (lower) in the Li metal/PEM/SS configuration at a scan rate of 1 mV/s; (c) variation of ionic conductivity versus reciprocal absolute temperature of various PEGDGE-co-Jeffamine ratios of 40 wt% of SCN and 40 wt% of Li salt showing the VTF character; (d) cyclic voltammetry (CV) scans in the Li metal/PEM/SS configuration at a scan rate of 1 mV/s of 20/40/40 PEGDA/SCN/LiTFSI in the potential range from −0.5 to 4.5 V exhibiting overlapping spectra, suggestive of reproducible stable CV behavior and (e) the corresponding CV scans of 20/40/40 PEGDGE-co-Jeffamine (70:30)/SCN/LiTFSI in the potential range from −0.5 to 4.5 V showing reproducible CV peaks at about 1.1 V and 2.1 V in the oxidation cycle and the corresponding 0.7 V and 1.3 V in the reduction cycle within the PEM potential range of 0 to 2.5 V (see the zoomed plot).

Cyclic voltammetry (CV) scans of the PEM - 20/40/40 PEGDA/SCN/LiTFSI in the Li metal/PEM/LFP configuration at a scan rate of 1 mV/s in the various potential ranges: (a) in full battery range covering from −0.5 to 4.5 V; (b) Li metal anode and PEM range from −0.5 V to 2.5 V; (c) only the PEM range from 0.01 to 2.5 V showing the supercapacitor behavior; (d) PEM plus cathode range from 0.01 to 4.5 V; and (e) the LFP cathode range from 2.5 to 4.5 V involving an oxidation peak at 3.7 V and a reduction peak at 3.2 V exhibiting electrochemically stable cycling behavior. Note that these CV cyclings were conducted continuously in the sequence of (a) to (e) to demonstrate the role of prelithiation in the electrochemical stability in all potential ranges.

(a, upper) Schematic of PEGDA and LiTFSI salt bilayer-PEM composite containing 30 wt% salt in the upper layer and 0 wt% in the bottom layer and (a, bottom) ion diffusion to the bottom layer after 4 days of aging. (b) FTIR scans in ATR reflection mode of the bilayer-PEM containing PEGDA and 30 wt% salt after 4 days of aging, showing the SO2 stretching and CF vibrating bands suggesting the diffusion of LiTFSI to the bottom layer after aging, and (c) FTIR spectra before and after CV tests showing the dissociated SO and CF spectra similar to those in panel (b).

(a) Schematic drawing of PEGDA and LiTFSI salt and their bilayer-PEM (bilayer composite containing 15 wt% salt upper layer and 0 wt% bottom layer in the PEM); (b) ionic conductivity of PEGDA/LiTFSI compositions; cyclic voltammetry of bilayer-PEM in the Li metal/PEM/SS configuration without SCN (c) after aging for 1 day showing an emergence of a minor peak around 2.1 V; (d) after 3 days, the dual peaks corresponding to oxidation at the PEM/SS electrode interface which become very pronounced (e) after 4 days, showing redox reaction peaks at the PEM/electrode interface (green arrow) as well as in the bulk (blue), and very small Li ions stripping at ~0.25 V (black arrow) at the Li metal electrode. Cyclic voltammetry of bilayer-PEM containing PEGDA and 30 wt% salt upper layer and 0 wt% bottom layer in the PEM after (f) 1 day, (g) 2 days, and (h) 3 days. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

Cyclic voltammetry (CV) plots of PEGDGE-co-Jeffamine (70:30) ratio by weight corresponding to 1:1 M ratio in the Li metal/PEM/LFP configuration at various potential ranges including, (a) the full battery potential range (−0.5 to 4.5 V), (b) Li metal anode and PEM covering −0.5 V ~ 2.5 V, (c) overlapping CV curves of the PEM voltage range from 0 V to 2.5 V, and (d) corresponding CV curves LFP cathode range from 2.5 V to 4.5 V.

Charge and discharge profiles for Li/PEGDGE-co-Jeffamine (70:30/40/40)/LFP cathode cells as a function of number of cycles within the range of (a) PEM (0.5 to 2.5 V) at a rate of 0.1C at 25 °C, (b) cathode (2.6 to 4.2 V) at a rate of 0.1C at 25 °C, and (c) full battery range (0.01 to 4.2 V) at a rate of 0.1C at 25 °C. (d) The corresponding capacity retention and Coulombic efficiency trends as a function of the number of cycles.

head.ce:title: Multifunctional polymer electrolyte membrane networks for energy storage via ion-dipole complexation in lithium metal battery

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: School of Polymer Science and Polymer Engineering, University of Akron, Akron, OH 44325, USA

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: School of Polymer Science and Polymer Engineering

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: School of Polymer Science and Polymer Engineering, University of Akron, Akron, Ohio 44325, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A novel concept of energy storage is presented involving ion-dipole complexation within multifunctional polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM), consisting of polyethylene glycol diacrylate (PEGDA) and succinonitrile (SCN) plasticizer and lithium bis-trifluoromethane sulfonyl imide (LiTFSI) salt. A similar complexation of lithium ions with ether oxygen and amine moieties occurs in the thermally cured poly(ethylene glycol) diglycidyl ether (PEGDGE) - polyether amine (Jeffamine D400, 2-arm) co-network. By virtue of the network functional groups, the ion transport is hindered which may be viewed as temporally holding of the Li ions, reminiscent of ion storage. Although some Li ions may be partially immobilized due to ion-dipole complexation, upon prelithiation via deep discharging the lithium metal/PEM/lithium iron phosphate (LFP) battery assembly to the low potential range of 0.01–0.5 V (i.e., oxidation at the Li metal anode), excess mobile Li ions become available that can travel to the cathode through the Li+ saturated complexation sites at ease, exhibiting high ionic conductivity with energy storage capability within the PEM matrix. Another way of supplying Li ions to PEM is through diffusion driven by ion concentration gradient between the two-layer PEM composite composed of a high salt concentration layer and a no-salt layer. The CV measurement was carried out as a function of aging time on the bilayer composite in the PEM potential range of 0.01 to 2.5 V, which indeed revealed a systematic emergence of redox reaction peaks, thereby validating the energy storing concept of the multifunctional PEM network.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: Energy storage systems such as lithium ion batteries (LIBs) have contributed significantly on well-being of our society in powering remote/portable electronic devices, sensors and actuators [1–18], which have now reached some levels of maturity for further development of high power, high energy storage systems to power all electric vehicles (EV). Rechargeable LIBs are regarded as energy efficient, cost-effective, and high-performance energy storage devices. Similar to traditional batteries, LIB consists of two oppositely charged electrodes, i.e., cathode and anode, and liquid electrolytes to facilitate ionic current of charges such as lithium ions while preventing internal flow of electrons during electrochemical operations [13]. At present, major electrolytes in lithium ion batteries are designed around organic electrolyte solvents by virtue of their high ionic conductivity, electrochemical stability, and low costs. However, these organic solvents have encountered high flammability risks due to their high reactivity and volatile nature in addition to their poor thermal and chemical stabilities [13–16]. To mitigate the aforementioned limitations associated with the organic liquid electrolytes, it is essential to develop safer and sustainable alternatives, which has led to development of solid electrolytes such as inorganic ceramic electrolyte (ICE) [19–21], solid polymer electrolyte (SPE) [22–27], and recently polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) (i.e., homogeneous amorphous networks without any crystals or phase separated structures) [28–44]. Solid PEMs are considered as superior replacements of organic liquid electrolytes, which show excellent battery safety and light weight with dimensional and electrochemical stabilities.

The present article focuses on the capability of storing extra lithium ions afforded by ion-dipole interaction in multifunctional polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM), which ultimately enhances battery storage capacity. Herein, prelithiation is performed to supply excess lithium ions from the lithium metal anode to the cathode through the multifunctional polymer electrolyte networks, which can be easily accomplished via deep discharging to the low potential range of Li metal electrode (i.e., −0.5 V to 0.5 V). It is well documented that mobile lithium cations are transported through the ion-dipole complexation sites with ether oxygen of polyether matrix. When additional functionalities such as carbonate, amine, urethane, nitrile, or sulfide moieties are imparted into the polymer matrix, Li ions can form complexation with some of the aforementioned functional groups, thereby rendering extra storage capacity within the PEM. It can be anticipated that the internal cell resistance could increase since entrapped Li ions are no longer participating in the overall lithium ion transport [23–28]. However, there are some excess lithium ions available afforded by the prelithiation process from the lithium metal anode, therefore there will be plenty of free, mobile lithium ions still available, and thus the Li ion transport remains very high. Of particular importance is that the present prelithiation process in principle permits the facile ion conduction as well as extra Li+ storage capacity inside the functional PEM network through ion-dipole interaction, which is not known for the conventional ‘inert’ organic liquid electrolyte system. Moreover, the population of anions remained unchanged before and after prelithiation, hence the ion transport is primarily dominated by the excess lithium ions. First, PEGDA/LiTFSI system was chosen in fabricating a bilayer composite containing LiTFSI salt in one layer and zero salt in the other layer to establish the proof-of-concept of the fact that the PEM can store energy through ion migration across the bilayer during aging leading to gradual emergence of oxidation and reduction peaks within the PEM voltage range. Second in support of the concept of energy storage ability of the PEM, poly(ethylene glycol) diglycidyl ether (PEGDGE)/Jeffamine (i.e., a basic ingredient of adhesive) co-network was chosen as PEM matrix to demonstrate the effect of prelithiation on the specific capacity enhancement afforded by ion-dipole interaction between dissociated lithium ions and amine functionality. The primary emphasis here is to elucidate the role of prelithiated polymer electrolyte membrane in lithium ion battery for storing extra Li ions in the continuum of multifunctional PEM networks, beyond the storage capacity afforded by a conventional cathode [32–40].

Telechelic diacrylate end-capped polyoxide precursor, poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA, Mn ~ 700 g/mol) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, which was used to form a crosslinked network via UV-photopolymerization with the aid of a photoinitiator (Irgacure 819, Sigma-Aldrich). A linear diepoxide precursor, poly(ethylene glycol) diglycidyl ether (PEGDGE, Mn ~ 500 g/mol) from Sigma-Aldrich and poly(propylene glycol) diamine (PPGDA, Jeffamine D-400, Mn ~ 430 g/mol) from Huntsman were thermally crosslinked at an elevate temperature of 80 °C to form the co-polymer. Plasticizer, i.e., succinonitrile (SCN) and lithium ionic salt, i.e., lithium bis(trifluoromethane sulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI, with a purity of over 98 %), were acquired from Sigma-Aldrich and then used as a source of Li+ cation and TFSI− anion within the polymer electrolyte membranes (PEMs). The materials for cathode such as lithium iron phosphate (LFP) and carbon black (Super P) were purchased from MTI Corporation. Cathode binder, poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF, Mn ~ 534,000) and a solvent, 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP, purity of 99.5 %) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich.

The binary LiTFSI/SCN melt mixture was prepared in the Argon gas chamber (often referred to Ar glove box) at a 50/50 weight ratio. PEGDA polymer precursor containing 3 wt% of photoinitiator was further mixed with the LiTFSI/SCN solution by rigorously stirring for 1 h at 50 °C to obtain homogeneous PEGDA/LiTFSI/SCN solution at the 30/35/35 weight ratios. Subsequently, the solution was poured into the prefabricated silicon mold and pre-cured by illuminating under uniform UV light (365 nm) for 10 s at 200 mW/cm2 to activate the photo-initiator and then the resulting gel-like film was cross-rolled sequentially in orthogonal directions to smooth out the film surface for improved contact and achieve uniform thickness. The cross-rolled PEM gel-like film was further cured at a higher UV intensity of 10 W/cm2 for 40 s, by allowing generated radicals to fully react with the CC double bonds of the PEGDA. The resulting polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) becomes a solid, completely amorphous film, which is flexible and twistable with homogeneous and transparent appearance.

PEGDGE and Jeffamine precursors were mixed at 70/30 (1:1 equivalent ratio), 75/25, and 80/20 weight ratios for 30 min at ambient temperature. LiTFSI salt and SCN plasticizer were mixed via eutectic melting at 60 °C at a 50/50 ratio by weight percent in the Ar glove box. Subsequently, the 50/50 LiTFSI/SCN mixture was further mixed with the PEGDGE/Jeffamine prepolymer mixture, at the weight ratio of 20/40/40 (prepolymer mixtures/SCN/LiTFSI). Subsequently, the homogeneous ternary mixture was stirred for 30 min at ambient and then poured into prefabricated molds followed by heating at 80 °C for 5 h by triggering the ring opening reaction between epoxy and amines to afford cross-linking into the co-network. The resulting PEGDGE-co-Jeffamine/SCN/LiTFSI - PEMs remained homogenous and transparent, suggestive of miscible character although by no means proof.

LFP, Super P (conductive carbon black), and PVDF were dried in a vacuum oven at 120 °C overnight. Subsequently, PVDF powder was dissolved fully in NMP solvent at the 10/90 wt% ratio. LFP, Super P carbon black, and PVDF were mixed in a Thinky® mixer at a weight ratio of 90/5/5 and the viscosity was controlled by the amount of NMP solvent used. The prepared cathode solution was coated on the Al foil in a coating machine using a coating bar at a speed of 3 mm/s. The gap between Al foil and the bar was 200 μm. Subsequently, the coated cathode was dried on a hot plate at 120 °C for 1 h and then transferred to a vacuum oven at 80 °C under vacuum to remove any residual NMP solvent from the cathode. The LFP cathode had uniform thickness of 70 μm which was stored in an Argon gas chamber prior to assembling with the PEM and lithium metal anode.

The prepared PEM solution was poured into home-made Teflon mold having a dimension of 10 mm × 10 mm × 1 mm (length × width × height) and cured by UV lamp. The sample heating cell was mounted on an AC impedance spectrometer (HP4192A, Hewlett-Packard) and the ionic conductivity of PEMs was determined by scanning at a rate of 1 °C/min from 25 °C to 100 °C under an applied voltage of 10 mV from 13 MHz to 5 Hz.

To determine electrochemical properties of PEM, lithium metal batteries were assembled by sandwiching it between Li metal anode and LFP cathode in a coin-cell (CR2032). To prevent both anode and cathode from current leaks from the edges, PEM films were cut in a slightly larger dimension, i.e., about 15 mm in diameter. Lithium metal/PEM/stainless steel (SS) configuration were used for linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), whereas cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests were performed for lithium metal/PEM/LFP coin cell batteries. Both LSV and CV tests were conducted using a Multi Autolab-M204 potentiostat at ambient. The LSV tests were carried out from 1 to 6 V at a scan rate of 1 mV/s. To evaluate their electrochemical stability and capacity retention, the CV scans were carried out at a rate of 1 mV/s within various potential ranges of −0.5–4.5 V, −0.5–2.5 V, 0–2.5 V, 0–4.5 V and 2.5–4.5 V, sequentially. Galvanostatic charge and discharge (GCD) cycling tests were performed in the lithium metal/PEM/LFP configuration in the potential range of 0.01–4.2 V, 0.5–2.5 V, and 2.6–4.2 V to determine the capacity retention at various charge/discharge rates.

First, polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) consisting of poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA), succinonitrile (SCN), and lithium bis(trifluoromethane sulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) was fabricated by means of UV curing at a ratio of 20/40/40 by weight percent. Secondly, to afford multifunctionality, thermal crosslinking reaction was carried out on the homogeneous mixture of polyethylene glycol diglycidyl ether (PEGDGE) and polypropylene glycol diamine (Jeffamine D400) precursor at a ratio of 70/30 by wt% through the so-called ring-opening polymerization of epoxide ring with primary amine by heating at 80 °C for 5 h in the presence of LiTFSI salt and SCN plasticizer (Fig. 1a).

Fig. 1b exhibits the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) scan of PEGDA-based PEM in comparison with that of PEGDGE-co-Jeffamine copolymer-based PEM containing comparable amount (40 wt% each) of SCN and LiTFSI salt. Both PEMs appear stable against the stainless-steel (SS) electrode for about up to 4.25 V as indicated by the arrows at the onsets of the CV curves. As depicted in Fig. 1c, the ionic conductivity of PEGDGE (70 wt%)/Jeffamine D400 (30 wt%) copolymer network/SCN/LiTFSI - PEM shows a slightly higher relative to that of PEGDA based PEM at the same composition (i.e., 20/40/40 PEGDA/SCN/LiTFSI by weight ratio), which is on the order of superionic conductor level of ~10−3 S cm−1 at the battery operating temperatures of 40–45 °C, since most batteries warm up during the operation. The transfer number of lithium ions in PEGDA polymer network was around 0.699 [31].

The corresponding cyclic voltammetry scans are depicted in Fig. 1d and e, which covered from −0.5 to 4.2 V and −0.5 to 4.5 V. Both oxidation and reduction peaks can be discerned at about 0.3 V and −0.5 V, respectively, corresponding to the lithium metal electrode and a minute peak around 4.2 V corresponding to the stainless-steel (SS) electrode. Of particular interest is the observation of minor peaks at about 1.1 V and 2.1 V in the oxidation cycle and the corresponding valleys (hereafter called ‘peaks’ for simplicity) at about 0.5 V and 1.3 V in the reduction cycle. Both oxidation and reduction peaks in the PEM potential range appear reproducible in repeated cycling for 5 cycles thus tested. However, unlike the liquid electrolyte system, minute dual oxidation peaks appear in the vicinity of 1.1 V and 2.1 V and the corresponding reduction peaks in the PEM potential range (around 0.7 V and 1.3 V) can be noticed for both PEGDA-based PEM and PEGDGE-co-Jeffamine based PEM.

In the case of the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) experiments, the starting potential is 0 V, which covers only the lithium ion stripping peak (i.e., oxidation peak of 0–0.5 V) without the lithium ion depositing peak (i.e., reduction peak from −0.5 to 0 V) of the lithium metal electrode. The stripped lithium ions are subsequently transported to the SS electrode through the PEM matrix. The LiTFSI salt in the PEM can be dissociated by ether oxygen as well as amine functionality. However, the dissociated and stripped Li ions can form coordination bonds with ether oxygen and/or amine groups through the so-called ion-dipole interaction within the co-network, whereby some charges may be temporarily withheld within these complexation sites. The dissociation and recombination of lithium cations with TFSI anions may be ascribed to the reversible reaction involving energy storage or release corresponding to the oxidation and reduction peaks in the CV potential range of the PEM (i.e., 1.1 V ~ 2.0 V and 0.5 V ~ 1.3 V). Since these peaks and valleys are reproducible in repeated CV cycling, suggesting that the dissociation and recombination processes of the Li ions from their salts are indeed reversible.

Next, the PEM was further assembled with lithium metal anode and LFP cathode in the battery configuration of Li metal/PEM/LFP, which was investigated by means of cyclic voltammetry (CV) within various potential ranges in the sequence of Fig. 2a–e. As can be witnessed from Fig. 2a, the redox reaction and oxidation peaks of the Li metal anode appeared at −0.5 V and 0.3 V and of the LFP cathode at 3.2 V and 3.7 V, respectively. The reduction and oxidation peaks at the low potential range reveal gradual decline in magnitude with increasing number of cycles which may be ascribed to loss of lithium ions. That is to say, the stripped Li ions from the Li metal anode during oxidation are transported to the cathode through the PEM matrix, which are temporarily withheld within the PEM network by forming complexation with ether oxygen and/or amine functionalities via ion-dipole interaction, and thus were not fully redeposited back to the Li metal anode during reduction. The gradual decline of the reduction peaks or loss of Li ions can also be confirmed in the −0.5 V ~ 2.5 V range covering both lithium metal anode and PEM potential ranges (Fig. 2b). This minor decline in the reduction peak (0.2 v and 1.1 V) may be attributed to the limited functionality available in the present PEM matrix containing only ether oxygen, and thus it can no longer hold the extra ions, some of which are redeposited back to the lithium metal anode. The revelation of the additional peaks between the lithium metal anode and LFP cathode potential ranges, appearing as minor shoulders at about 1.0 V ~ 2.3 V in the oxidation cycle and the corresponding 0.3 V ~ 1.5 V in the reduction scan, may be attributable to the redox reaction within the PEM (Fig. 2a and b).

It should be pointed out that the minute, but still noticeable peaks at 0.3 V and 1.5 V are at odd with the general perception of the requirement of ‘inertness’ in electrolyte, which are often misinterpreted as an indication of electrolyte instability or a signature of battery failure. A natural question is, if the PEM electrolytes were unstable, why these observed redox peaks in PEM range are reversible and reproducible. The most crucial characteristic of a conventional liquid electrolyte battery is its inertness towards the electrode for the stable operation of the battery. The characteristic inertness to resist any changes in electrolyte composition is the required condition of electrochemical stability in the organic liquid electrolyte system, but such ‘inert’ concept of liquid electrolyte cannot explain the present observed behavior of energy storing solid polymer electrolyte battery.

As shown in Fig. 2c–e, three different potential ranges were investigated sequentially covering −0.5 V ~ 2.5 V, 0.01 V ~ 2.5 V, and 0.01 V ~ 4.5 V in order to elucidate the origins of the peak height (or magnitude) and/or the area within the PEM voltage range. Of particular interest is that all the CV spectra in subsequent cycles are all overlapped suggestive of outstanding electrochemical stability after prelithiation during the initial cyclings in Fig. 2a and b. Note that this prelithiation step corresponds to the battery conditioning process.

Another notable feature is the shape of the CV spectrum in the PEM range (Fig. 2c) which is reminiscent of a supercapacitor such as Helmholtz electric double layer capacitor (EDLC) or Faradic pseudocapacitor involving redox reaction with the PEM matrix. Although the strength (or magnitude) of current density is considerably smaller relative to the actual supercapacitor using symmetric or asymmetric carbonaceous electrodes such as graphene oxide, carbon nanotube, or activated carbon which can store sizable amount of charges, therefore higher energy. In the present case, the PEM is sandwiched between the Li metal anode and the LFP cathode that contains a small amount of carbon black (10 wt%) and thus only a limited amount of lithium ions can undergo polarization/depolarization against the electrons pertaining to conductive carbons at the cathode interface, reminiscent of an EDLC behavior, and thus it is not surprising to discern a small magnitude of the current density, i.e., very low energy storage. However, it opens a new opportunity to design a PEM matrix by incorporating various multifunctional groups and/or modify the cathode by increasing the amount of carbonaceous materials or other types of high capacity carbons such as graphene, carbon nanotube, or active carbon. Increasing the conductive carbon amount or functional polymer binder is again contradictory to the customary approach in the cathode design, in which the amount of active materials such as LFP or NMC is raised beyond the present standard 80/10/10 active materials/PVDF/electron conductive carbon black, to over 90 % of active materials, viz., 90/5/5 or 95/2.5/2.5 as a mean of improving energy storage capacity in the cathode. As can be noticed in Fig. 2d and e, the overlapping CV curves in the cathode range implies the electrochemical stable character of the LFP cathode.

Next, to elucidate the role of ion-dipole complexation within the PEM matrix, the PEM composition was simplified to a binary system consisting of PEGDA having only one functional type (i.e., ether oxygen) and Li salt without using any plasticizer. A composite assembly composed of 30 wt% LiTFSI and 70 wt% PEGDA precursor and 0 wt% (neat PEGDA) was fabricated via photopolymerization (Fig. 3a, upper). Initially, this composite was not ion conductive since the neat PEGDA network is an insulator. Upon aging for 4 days, the composite assembly becomes ion conductive as the LiTFSI salt was dissociated due to its interaction with ether oxygen of the PEGDA (Fig. 3a, bottom). The diffusion of dissociated TFSI anions was monitored by using the IR beam in reflective mode. As shown in Fig. 3b, the IR spectra of before aging and after 4 days of aging revealed the emergence of SO2 and CF3 vibrating bands belonging to the TFSI anions. The cyclic voltammetry tests were performed on the bilayer composite before and after aging for 4 days. The FTIR scans revealed the emergence of the SO2 and CF3 bands after 4 days of aging reminiscent of the spectra shown in Fig. 3b, which confirmed that the ions are redistributed within the bilayer composites. The binary PEGDA/LiTFSI based PEM containing 15 wt% lithium salt was also prepared to compare with the PEM containing 30 wt% salt. Next, various PEGDA/LiTFSI compositions were tested for ionic conductivity using the AC impedance spectroscopy as a function of temperature from ambient to 100 °C in Fig. 4b. The binary PEM containing 30 wt% LITFSI becomes ion conductive, but the ionic conductivity is rather low which is in the range of 10−4 mS cm−1 at ambient temperature, which increases to 10−1 mS cm−1 at 100 °C. With increasing the salt contents, ionic conductivity increases in which the 50 wt% salt shows the highest conductivity among the three PEMs tested (Fig. 4b).

Subsequently, the CV tests were performed on the 15 wt% and 30 wt% LiTFSI salts containing bilayer PEM composites. Initially, the CV test was not possible for the as-prepared bilayer PEM composite since the bottom layer contained no salt and thus it is practically an insulator. By virtue of the potential (or ion concentration) gradient between the two layers (Fig. 4a), dissociated ions gradually diffuse from the top to the bottom layers. Upon aging for 1 day, the cyclic voltammogram starts to reveal the emergence of a very tiny current peak on the order of ~5 × 10−5 mAh/g, as some dissociated lithium cations and TFSI anions started to diffuse into the bottom layer. The bilayer composite subsequently becomes ion-conductive, showing an emergence of very small current response (about 5 × 10−5 mAh/g) with a very broad shoulder peak emerging in the vicinity of 2.1 V, as indicated by an arrow in Fig. 4c. Such a small current is not surprising since the amount of Li ion concentration is too small (15 wt%) to begin with. With increasing aging time to 3 days, the emerged shoulder peak becomes more pronounced (see Fig. 4d), which subsequently splits into dual peaks upon aging for 4 days (Fig. 4e) showing over one order of magnitude increase in the current density (i.e., ~10−4 mAh/g). A minor Li+ stripping peak also emerges at about 0.2 V, while these dual reduction peaks (i.e., discharge current) also intensify at 0.3 V and 1.1 V and become noticeable after 4 days of aging. These dual peaks during charging and discharging may be unambiguously assigned to the oxidation and reduction reactions occurring at the PEM/electrode interface and within the bulk PEM, respectively. Note that the present PEGDA has limited functionality, i.e., ether oxygen that can form coordination bonds with Li+ and thus it has limited Li ion storage capacity, therefore the observed current density is relatively very small due to the limited available ether group of the PEM network. Nevertheless, the Li ion storage capability of the PEM can be unambiguously confirmed.

Next, the CV experiment was extended to the bilayer composite PEM containing a larger amount of lithium salt (30 wt% LiTFSI) in the upper layer (Fig. 4a). As can be seen in Fig. 4f, the emergence of the redox reaction peaks becomes more pronounced after 1 day of aging (Fig. 4f). With further aging for 2 and 3 days, the magnitude of current density increases drastically for about one order of magnitude (i.e., ~10−3 mAh/g) while exhibiting the enhanced redox reaction peaks in the PEM voltage range (Fig. 4g and h). This observation is not surprising because more mobile lithium ions are available in the higher salt content bilayer composite that do not involve in the ion-dipole complexation with electrophilic groups of polymer network and thus can move relatively easily to the opposite electrode. It is reasonable to infer that the oxidation peaks at ~1.2 V and ~2.1 V and the corresponding reduction peaks at ~0.5 V and ~1.1 V are influenced by the ion-dipole complexation via coordination bonding between ether oxygen of the PEM network and Li ions from its TFSI salt. The present CV observation undoubtedly points to the fact that these redox peaks indeed belong to the PEM, suggesting extra energy storage inside the PEM in the voltage range of 0.3 to 2.5 V in addition to that of the LFP cathode in the range of 2.5 to 4.5 V.

In an attempt to increase the ion-dipole complexation sites, the multifunctional PEM matrix was fabricated using PEGDGE (polyethylene glycol end-capped with epoxy) and Jeffamine D400 (i.e., polypropylene oxide in the backbone terminated by diamine) for thermal curing at an elevated temperature of 80 °C. The choice of this co-polymer pair is the plausible continuous online melt-processability and scalability. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was performed on the PEGDGE-co-Jeffamine (70/30) ratio by weight corresponding to 1:1 M ratio in the Li metal anode/PEM/LFP cathode configuration.

As can be witnessed in Fig. 5a, the redox reaction and oxidation peaks of the Li metal anode appeared in the potential range of −0.5 V ~ 0.3 V and those of the LFP cathode in the voltage range of 2.9 V ~ 3.7 V. In the PEM potential range at about 0.5 V to 2.4 V, which is between lithium metal anode and LFP cathode peaks, the current density has increased for a few orders of magnitude to ~10−1 mAh/g (or 0.2 mAh/g) due to additional amine functionality in the PEM for extra complexation with lithium ions coupled with enhanced network chain mobility afforded by the SCN plasticization. More importantly, these CV curves are virtually overlapped for repeated cycles exhibiting a distorted loop, due to the oxidation peak of Li metal anode and tiny redox reaction peaks of PEM, showing a pseudocapacitor-like character. More importantly, the above finding, albeit minute, attests to the energy storage capability of the PEM networks like a capacitor. It is evident that lithium cations from lithium metal cathode were stored not only by the LFP active materials, but also by the PEM within its potential range (0.3 V ~ 2.5 V), which is reproduceable (see Fig. 5b and c). Compared to PEGDA-based PEM in Fig. 2, the reduction peaks PEM are one order of magnitude higher in Fig. 4b and c, since polymer co-networks contained more functional groups such as ether oxygen and amine groups, but also the SCN plasticizer which also serves as an ionizer to dissociate the lithium salt for enhanced complexation. By virtue of the ion-dipole complexations of between lithium cations and ether oxygen and/or amine, the ability of PEM for storing lithium ions was further enhanced as manifested by the higher peak intensity, which is almost comparable to the LFP cathode peaks in Fig. 5d.

In support of the above argument on the energy storing capability of the present PEM, charge/discharge cycling tests were performed at room temperature up to 50 cycles. Fig. 6 a show the variation of specific capacity versus number of cycles of PEM range. By virtue of the pseudocapacitor and/or electric double layer capacitor, the oxidation and reduction reaction peaks can be discerned in the vicinity of ~1.7 V and ~1.45 V, respectively. The PEM has its own specific capacity from about 39.3 mAh/g initially which rapidly declined to about 25.2 mAh/g after 50 cycles and subsequently stabilized. Coulombic efficiency was found to be approximately 99 %. The specific capacity of LFP cathode in the potential range between 2.6 V and 4.2 V is initially 152 mAh/g, and it decreases to about 142.5 mAh/g after 50th cycle with the Coulombic efficiency of about 99 % in Fig. 6b and d.

To further confirm the electrochemical stability of the in-situ lithiated PEM based rechargeable battery, the galvanometric charge/discharge cycling test was performed from 0.01 V ~ 4.2 V (Fig. 6c and d). The specific capacity is ~185 mAh/g initially that decreases to about 151.5 after 50th cycle with the Coulombic efficiency of ~99 %. Of particular interest is that the specific capacity obtained from the in-situ lithiated PEM battery is higher than the experimentally observed capacity of the LFP cathode (i.e., 152 mAh/g initially that stabilized at 142.5 mAh/g) due to the extra energy storage capability of PEGDGE-co-Jeffamine copolymer electrolyte membrane, having a wider operating potential window of 0.01 to 4.2 V with a higher specific capacity. It is reasonable to infer that the SCN-plasticized PEGDGE-co-Jeffamine based PEM is capable of storing extra energy (i.e., about 25.2 mAh/g after 50th cycle) beyond that of the LFP cathode (i.e., ~142.5 mAh/g after 50th cycle) and thus the full battery would yield a total specific capacity of about 168.7 mAh/g after 50th cycle.

In summary, the role of ion-dipole complexation in energy storage within polymer electrolyte membrane was investigated for both PEGDA network and PEGDGE-co-Jeffamine polymer co-network containing LiTFSI salt. Both PEMs containing SCN plasticizer and LiTFSI salt exhibited high ionic conductivity at a level (>10−3 S cm−1) at ambient or at least at the battery operating temperature of 45 °C. The ion-dipole complexation between lithium ions and ether oxygen and/or amine moieties in the thermally cured poly(ethylene glycol) diglycidyl ether (PEGDGE) - polyether amine (Jeffamine D400, 2-arm) co-network, presumably hampered the ion transport which may be viewed as temporally holding of the Li ions or ion storage. Although Li ion transport may be hindered due to ion-dipole complexation, excess mobile Li ions are still available upon prelithiation which can travel to the cathode through the Li+ saturated complexation sites indicating energy storing ability of the PEM matrix. The proof-of-concept of energy storage was established by means of the CV measurement in the potential range of 0.01 to 2.5 V as a function of aging time, (i.e., ion diffusion through the two-layer PEM composite having ion concentration gradients) which revealed a systematic emergence of redox reaction peaks, thereby validating the energy storing concept of the functional PEGDA network. The PEGDGE-co-Jeffamine system exhibits approximately 25.2 mAh/g after 50th cycle and almost 100 % Columbic efficiency in the PEM voltage range (0.5–2.5 V), whereas about 142.5 mAh/g at 50th cycle was obtained within the LFP cathode range (2.6–4.2 V), and thus the overall energy in the full battery range (0.01–4.2 V), i.e., ~185 mAh/g which stabilized at about 151.5 mAh/g after 50 cycles. It should be pointed out that specific capacities of the present cathode are slightly higher than those (i.e., about 140–120 mAh/g) of a conventional liquid electrolyte lithium ion battery. Although the amount of energy storage improvement by the present PEM may be very small, i.e., only about 25.2 mAh/g after 50th cycle, the proof-of-concept can now be established which opens an opportunity for exploring new strategies by attaching various multifunctional groups such as ester, carbonate, urethane, or thiol groups for further enhancement of energy storage capacity within the polymer electrolyte networks.
